Adela has borrowed and repaid six loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for three years and also earns additional income from buying and selling scrap.

Adela aspires to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy more stock, such as soft-drinks, snack foods, noodles, biscuits, and cooking oil, to sell in her general store.

loans.name: Analiza

texts.en:
Analiza is 22 years old and has an 11-month-old baby boy. She lives in Ubay, Bohol with her child. She has owned a sari-sari store for a year, selling canned goods, chips, noodles, eggs and toiletries.

She is asking for a loan of 6,000 PHP to buy a piglet to raise additional income. By adding this business, she will be better equipped to raise her young son.  

In the future, she hopes to have a better business option to maximize her income and to provide a higher quality of life for her son.

loans.use: to buy a piglet.

loans.name: Mario Antonio

texts.es:
María, se dedica a la venta de bebidas y leña.  El está soltero, tiene 20 años de edad, tiene dos hermanos  y vive con sus padres; el oficio lo realiza desde hace dos años y su padre le ayuda a llevarlo a cabo.
El préstamo que requiere le permitirá comprar variedad de bebidas tales como: jugos, sodas, entre otros y asimismo leña para después venderla;  esta inversión le ayudara a incrementar sus inventarios y obtener mejores ingresos.
Su sueño es fortalecer el negocio y brindarle una mejor calidad de vida a su familia.
texts.en:
Mario is in the business of selling beverages and firewood. He is single and twenty years old. He has two brothers and lives with his parents. He has run his business for two years and his father helps him carry it out.

The loan he needs will help him purchase a variety of beverages such as juice and soda, as well as firewood, which he will then sell. This investment will help him to increase his inventory and his income.

His dream is to strengthen his business and give his family a better quality of life.

loans.use: purchase beverages such as juice and soda, as well as firewood for resale.

loans.name: Alita

texts.en:
Alita is 51 years old and married with one child. She earns a living by farming rice in the Philippines. Alita has been farming rice for 20 years and also earns additional income from a general store.

Alita is borrowing 29,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) through NWTF to pay for laborer's salaries and the purchase of fertilizers. She successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further build her sugarcane farming and general store. She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to pay for laborer's salaries and the purchase of fertilizers.

loans.name: Lita

texts.en: Lita is 52 years old and lives in Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur. She cooked and sold snacks in the local community for a living for 5 years, earning 5,000 PHP a month. She became a member of GDMPC in 2008 and is requesting a loan of PHP 7,000 to purchase ingredients such as flour, sugar, oil and additional untensils. Positively, she wants to improve/expand her business to have a better future.

loans.use: to purchase ingredients such as flour, sugar, oil and additional untensils.

location.town: Santo Nino, Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur

loans.name: Ana Heriberta

texts.es:
Ana, se le presenta la necesidad de optar por un nuevo préstamo para seguir invirtiendo en el negocio; este le permitirá comprar variedad de ropa para dama tales como: blusas, pantalones, camisas, chores y asimismo surtir la tienda  con azucar, frijoles, arroz, entre otros.
El crédito anterior le ayudo a incrementar sus inventarios y obtener mayores ingresos; las condiciones económicas y las circunstancias familiares han cambiado.
texts.en:
Ana found herself needing to take out another loan so that she can continue investing in her business. This will allow her to buy a variety of women's clothing such as blouses, pants, shirts, and shorts, while at the same time stocking her store with sugar, beans, and rice, among other goods.

The previous loan helped her to increase her inventory and earn greater income. Her economic and familial circumstances have changed.

loans.use: purchase women's blouses, pants, shirts and shorts, while at the same time stocking her store with sugar, beans, and rice, among other goods.

loans.name: Mamuka

texts.en:
Mamuka is 21 years old. He lives in the small village of Lagodekhi District with his mother. Mamuka has requested a loan from local financial institutions several times for a family business start-up but without any success. His loan request was rejected all the time because of low income and the family’s poor living conditions. 

The family has a milking cow. Mamuka’s mother milks the cow and produces dairy products for selling. Mamuka also has a bakery and bakes Georgian bread. It is hardly enough food for the family. According to Credo estimations, the family belongs to the subsistence poor category. 

Mamuka requested a loan from Credo to start a family business. Mamuka has now been approved for a loan within the framework of the new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages a provision for business start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions to rural poor people who do not have access to credit products. These rural poor people are regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of their low income. With his loan Mamuka, will purchase the raw materials for baking Georgian cheese bread. He will sell it at local schools and markets with bread. Offering more products to his clients will increase the income of his family. The new business initiative, financed with the Kiva Start-up loan, will significantly improve the living conditions of the family.

loans.use: to purchase raw materials and to bake Georgian cheese bread.

loans.name: Perpetua

texts.en:
Perpetua is a married woman and a mother of two children from Loon, Bohol. Perpetua runs a sari-sari or variety store business, selling various goods and items to the people in her area. This is the source of her income.

Perpetua is asking for a loan to buy additional stock to sell like canned goods, soda and beverages, noodles, rice, and other items. Through this, she will be able to attract and cater to more buyers in her store thus augmenting her sales and income. In the future, Perpetua dreams of expanding her store so that it will generate more revenue.

loans.use: to buy additional stock to sell like canned goods, soda and beverages, noodles, rice, and other items

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn is 35 years old and married with four children.

Jocelyn works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a 29,500 PHP loan through NWTF to buy items to sell like shampoo, soap, sugar, coffee, canned goods, spices, etc.

Jocelyn has borrowed and paid back 25 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for two years and also earns an income from fishing.

Jocelyn aspires to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy items to sell like shampoo, soap, sugar, coffee, canned goods, spices, etc.

loans.name: Edna

texts.en: Edna is 42 years old, married, and the mother of four children. She lives in Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur where she has earned a living for the last five years by selling  grocery items in the local community. She makes 8,000 PHP a month and is applying for a loan for 10,000 PHP to purchase additional products like canned goods, noodles, sugar, and coffee. She joined GDMPC in 2012 as a way to improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase additional products like canned goods, noodles, sugar, and coffee.

loans.name: Chizi

texts.en:
Chizi is 42 years old and is married. She and her husband live at their own house that does not have electricity nor piped water. 

For years, she has operated a vegetable stall business, selling from her home to her neighbors and passersby. Her major business challenge is price fluctuations. Chizi dreams of establishing a wholesale vegetable stall in the future. 

With the KES 40,000 loan, she wants to purchase sacks of green vegetables, tomatoes, potatoes and onions. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase green vegetables, tomatoes, potatoes and onions.

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en: Jocelyn runs a sari-sari, or variety store, business selling various goods and items to the people in her place. She is asking for a loan to buy more stocks of items to sell such as soap, detergents, shampoo, insect repellant coil, noodles, and canned goods. Through this, she will be able to improve her store and attract more buyers, thus increasing her sales and income.

loans.use: to buy soap, detergents, shampoo, insect repellant coil, noodles, and canned goods to sell.

loans.name: Musarrat

texts.en:
Musarrat is a very hardworking woman. She lives in Lahore, Pakistan with her family. She is a mother of 1 son. She is an independent and decent lady. Her husband is a poor man and does not have much income to cover his family's daily expenses. Therefore, Musarrat is trying to help her husband in generating income.

She owns a tailoring school in her community. She teaches stitching skills and generates income for her family. Musarrat wants to purchase chairs and sewing machines for her tailoring school. However due to the lack of finances she finds it difficult. Therefore, she has asked for a loan from Kiva's partner BRAC Pakistan to cover the cost of the items needed for her school. She hopes that the loan will be helpful for the development of her business. She is thankful to Kiva and BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: to purchase chairs and sewing machines for her tailoring school

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca is 48 years old and has nine children, two of whom are in school. Rebecca works very hard to provide for them.

Rebecca runs a buy and sell charcoal business in the Philippines and requested a 27,000 PHP loan through NWTF to purchase additional sacks of charcoal to sell.  Rebecca has been in this business for 8 years.

In the future Rebecca would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional sacks of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en: Teresita is from Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur. She's a 48-year-old married woman wirh 6 children. She has owned and operated a sari-sari store (general store) at home for the past 3 years and earns 6,000 PHP monthly from business operations. She became a GDMPC member in 2011, and is now requesting a loan of 9,000 PHP to purchase new items such as candies, milo, shampoo, soaps, etc. She hopes to sustain the store's revolving funds to prolong business operations.

loans.use: to purchase new items such as candies, milo, shampoo, soaps, etc.

loans.name: Chung

texts.en:
Chung was born in 1979. She has two children. They are attending primary and secondary school. Her husband is a carpenter and earns about 4,000,000 Viet Nam Dongs (VND) per month. Chung works as a farmer and a carpenter. She gains 4,000,000 VND a month. Her family’s total earnings are about 8,000,000 VND per month. 

Chung has participated in the Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance (SEDA) credit program since 2011. In the last cycle, she borrowed 6,322,000 VND and repaid the loan on time. In this loan cycle, Chung would like to borrow 7,630,000 VND to buy wood for her carpentry workshop. She  wants to raise her children well, so they can get a job in the future.

loans.use: to buy wood for her carpentry workshop

loans.name: Mbeyu

texts.en: Mbeyu appeals to you again for a new loan to supplement the previous one by adding stock to her business. She plans to purchase more goats for resale to her customers to satisfy their needs.  She thanks Yehu and Kiva for the help.

loans.use: to purchase more goats for resale.

loans.name: Editha

texts.en:
Editha is 41 years old and married. She has ten children, three of whom are in school.

Editha is in the agriculture business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for four years now, and has borrowed from NWTF 11 times in the past to sustain it. She is now requesting a loan of 20,000 Philippine Pesos (PHP) through NWTF to buy additional feed and vitamins for her pigs.

In the future, Editha would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to school.

loans.use: to buy additional feed and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Erving Manuel

texts.es: El señor Erving Manuel A. C. habita en la comunidad de los Ríos, del municipio de Ticuantepe, casado, padre de un niño pequeño, trabaja desde muy temprana edad, con el apoyo de sus padres pudo adquirir un terreno para laborar en esta actividad, ahora tiene  una experiencia de más de 15 años, sus palnes a futuro es tener su casa propia para darle a su hijo las mejores condicones posibles.  Con  este préstamo comprara los fertilizantes, fungicidas, e insumos vegetativos que permitan atacar la afectación de plagas y los problemas del suelo, esta inversión favorecerá su economía para la inversión a futuro de nuevos fuentes de trabajo o la reinversión a su negocio, y de esta manera irse labrando su futuro y estabilidad economica.
texts.en:
Erving Manuel lives in Los Ríos in the city of Ticuantepe. He is married and the father of a young child. He began working at an early age, and, with his parents' help, he was able to buy farmland. He now has 15 years of experience. His plan is to have his own house to offer his son the best possible living conditions. 

He will use this loan to buy fertilizer, weed killer, and organic supplies to prevent disease and other soil problems. This investment will improve his finances so that he can create new jobs or invest in his business and improve his future and financial situation.

loans.use: to maintain his crops.

loans.name: Haykanush

texts.en:
Haykanush is from the Arapi village in the Shirak region where she lives with her husband, mother-in-law, and 11-year-old son.

In the Winter season, Haykanush's husband goes abroad and supports his family financially, but their farming business helps them to have stable income during the month and cover their daily costs. 

Their farm currently includes three cows and two pigs. They also cultivate barley and potato and grow apple and pear trees with great love and care. The gathered harvest is sold locally, and this helps the family to sustain their living.
 
As it is very difficult for Haykanush to save money for the expansion of the farm (all their income is spent on covering basic costs), she has applied to SEF International for a loan. With the loan's help Haykanush will purchase potato and lucerne seeds and will be able to gather more harvest.

The expansion of the farm is vital for Haykanush to sustain her family and ensure better future for her son.

loans.use: to pay for potato and lucerne (alfalfa) seeds

loans.name: Candelaria

texts.en:
Candelaria is 54 years old and from the town of Ubay, Bohol. She is married and her husband works as a rice farmer.    

Candelaria sells fresh fish in the highway where there are customers who have been patronizing her business for 20 years now. She is asking for a loan of 25,000 PHP to buy more fish, soft drinks, and groceries for family consumption. 

In the future, she hopes to have enough savings and live a comfortable life .

loans.use: to buy fish, soft drinks, and groceries.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
For the past years, Josephine has operated a charcoal-selling business. She sells from home to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of high cost of transportation. She dreams of expanding her business to a wholesale supplier of charcoal in the village. 

With the 50,000 KES, she wants to purchase sacks of charcoal for resale. She decided to join to Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of charcoal for resale.

loans.name: Marine

texts.en:
Marine is 60 years old. She lives in the small village of Gurjaani. Marine requested a loan from local financial institutions several times to start up a family business but did not have any success. Her loan requests were rejected each time because of her low income and their family’s poor living conditions. 

Marine's retirement pension is her only source of income. According to Credo estimations, she belongs to the subsistence poor category. 

Marine requested a loan from Credo to start up a family business. Marine has now been approved for a loan within the framework of the new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages providing business start-up and re-start-up credits with soft conditions to rural poor people who do not have access to credit products. These rural poor people are regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of their low income. With this credit Marine will purchase chicks. After purchasing the chicks, she will raise them and resell them at higher price. This will increase her income. The new business initiative, financed with the Kiva start-up loan will significantly improve Marine's living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase chicks.

loans.name: Den-Den

texts.en:
This is Den-Den. Her previous loan was a big help to her business. She was able to buy the materials needed in her barber shop. The loan also helped in the household expenditures and in the education of her children. She has been in this business for eight years now. She and her husband are working hard to provide income for their everyday needs.

She would like to apply for another 30,000 PHP loan to buy new equipment and materials needed for her barber shop. Her profits from business will definitely help provide for her daily needs and educational expenses of her children. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Den-Den's dream is for her business to grow even more and to have another branch. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for new equipment and materials needed for her barber shop

loans.name: Caridad

texts.en:
Caridad is from Ubay, Bohol. She is 60 years old. She is a widow and relies on rice farming and selling candles for an income. This has been her source of livelihood for 20 years now. She is asking for a loan of 16,000 Philippine Pesos (PHP) to buy more candles and fertilizer and seedlings for her farm. This will allow her to continue farming and assure her healthy crops to harvest in four months. The income she earns from this will provide her food and other household expenses. 

Caridad only hopes that she is always healthy so she can support herself in the future.

loans.use: to buy candles, fertilizer and seedlings.

loans.name: Felista

texts.en:
Felista lives in the Muranga area of Kenya, which is a heavy pineapple-producing region. Her primary income sources are milk and crops.  She has three children and has been doing this work for 8 years. Felista's highest monthly expense is school fees. When asked how the loan will benefit her family, Felista replied, "Income from milk will cater to family needs" and help her pay her children's school fees.

What Felista enjoys most about farming is "Success and returns from my work." Her biggest challenge is "general management." Animals on the farm have been given the names of Ricky, Otis, and Mueni.

Felista was asked why she chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan, to which she replied that "Juhudi has favourable terms."  She was also asked what she learned during Juhudi's required micro-finance training session, and she explained that "It supports farmers in improving their livelihood by financing farm assets."

As part of Juhudi's loan appraisal process, each borrower's assets are evaluated. Felista owns the following: "cow, bicycle, automobile." She does not own pigs, poultry, a pump, or a motorcycle. Juhudi Kilimo also tries to measure any change in living standards based on this loan. This borrower has in the household a mosquito net, electricity, running water, TV, and DVD, but does not have solar power or a sewing machine.

Note: To create this loan profile, Juhudi Kilimo used a mobile device to gather information in the field and send the data to a central online repository, thus reducing paper use, making the process more efficient, and keeping costs down.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow.

loans.name: Al-Rbab Group

texts.en:
Al-Rbab group consists of four ladies from Taiz, Yemen. Each member has her own type of business. They have requested a group loan of 200,000 YER, and they will hold each other accountable for loan repayment. 

Basma is 26 years old. She is an uneducated woman from a poor family. The income of her husband is not enough to cover living expenses so she decided to help her husband and earn some money to provide better living conditions. She has been selling foods such as vegetables and fruits.  She applied for a youth loan of 50,000 YER from AMB to buy foods, vegetable and fruits to keep and expand her business. She looks forward to making large profits.

loans.use: to buy vegetables and fruits to sell.

loans.name: Maria Concepcion

texts.es:
María, solicita un nuevo préstamo por la necesidad de seguir invirtiendo en su negocio; este le permitirá comprar productos de primera necesidad tales como: maíz, frijoles, sodas, jugos, entre otros.
El crédito anterior le ayudo a incrementar sus ganancias y las utilidades las invirtió en gastos del hogar; las condiciones económicas han mejorado, ya que los hijos continúan estudiando y las circunstancias familiares se han optimizado.
texts.en:
María is asking for a new loan so that she can continue to invest in her business. This will let her purchase the most important goods such as corn, beans, soda, and juices, among others.

Her previous loan helped her to increase her earnings, and she invested the profits in her home expenses.  Her economic situation has improved, now that her children continue to stay in school and her family's circumstances have been improved.

loans.use: purchase corn, beans, soda, and juice, among other items.

loans.name: Luz Veronica

texts.es:
Luz tiene 21 años de edad es soltera no tiene hijos, vive con la familia en la ciudad de Guaranda Provincia de Bolívar.
Es integrante de la Ventanilla  Los pinos, se encuentra formada por 14 socios que son de la misma comunidad, se dedican a la agricultura queda a 40 minutos de la oficina Comunidad Pangua.
Luz se dedica a la agricultura a la siembra de papas y crianza de ganado. Solicita el crédito para comprar un terreno. Con la ayuda del crédito podrá comprar el terreno para sembrar maíz.  La compra lo realizará en la ciudad de Guaranda. 
El sueño es hacer una casa. Los desafíos a los que se enfrenta es la competencia. En el tiempo libre le gusta ir de paseo y disfrutar del carnaval.
texts.en:
Luz is 21, single, and has no children. She lives with her family in the city of Guaranda in Bolívar province. Los pinos (The Pines), the communal bank she belongs to, has 14 members who live in the area. They farm land within 40 minutes of the Pangua office. 

Luz grows potatoes and raises cattle. She has applied for a loan to buy land to grow corn. She buys and sells in the city of Guaranda. She dreams of owning a house. Among the challenges she faces is competition to her business. In her free time, she likes to go for a walk and to enjoy the carnival.

loans.use: to buy land.

loans.name: Maria Estela

texts.es:
María, requiere de más capital de trabajo para llevar a cabo su actividad, por lo que solicita un nuevo préstamo; este le permitirá comprar tintes, cremas, esmaltes, entre otros productos de cosmetología.
El crédito anterior  le ayudo a incrementar el inventario y aumento en las ventas; las condiciones económicas y las circunstancias familiares han mejorado.
texts.en:
María needs more working capital to do her activity. That is why she is asking for a new loan. This will allow her to buy dyes, creams, nail polish, and other cosmetology products.

The previous loan helped her to increase her inventory and her sales. Her family's finances and circumstances have improved.

loans.use: to buy dyes, creams, nail polish, and other cosmetology products.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary lives in the Muranga area of Kenya, which lies in the central Rift Valley. She has four children and has been doing this work for 27 years. Her primary income sources are milk and crops.

She stated what is most enjoyable about farming: "The returns from my investments and success." Her biggest challenge is "Finding a market for her farm products." Animals on the farm have been given the names of "Mulevu, Catelina, and Mumbua."

Mary was asked why she chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan, to which she replied: "Because it helps farmers in acquiring assets." This client was also asked what was learned during Juhudi's required micro-finance training session: "Provides small scale farmers with farming assets."

Her highest monthly expense is farming costs. When asked how this loan will benefit her family, Mary replied "By uplifting living standards with income from milk sales."

As part of Juhudi's loan appraisal process, each borrower's assets are evaluated. Mary owns the following: "cow, poultry, pump, and bicycle" but does not own "pig, motorcycle, or automobile." Juhudi Kilimo also tries to measure any change in living standards based on this loan. This borrower has in the household "mosquito net, electricity, running water, TV, and DVD" but does not have "solar power or a sewing machine."

Note: To create this loan profile, Juhudi Kilimo used a mobile device to gather information in the field and send the data to a central online repository, thus reducing paper use, making the process more efficient, and keeping costs down.

loans.use: to purchase a dairy cow.

loans.name: Susana

texts.en:
As a married parent of two children, Susana works hard to support her family.

She has a business buying and selling vegetables in the Philippines, and she also earns additional income from a general store. Susana is borrowing 12,000 PHP through NWTF to buy additional vegetables for her business of buying and selling vegetables.

Susana has been sustaining her business activities through her past loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy additional vegetables for her business.

loans.name: Nelia

texts.en:
This is Nelia. Her previous loan was a big help in her business. She was able to buy the needed merchandise for her direct-selling business. The loan also helped in their household expenditure. She is in this business for five years now. She works hard to provide for their everyday needs.

She would like to apply for another 15,000 PHP for her to buy more merchandise items and products to increase her product inventory. The more items displayed at the store the better. More items to sell will result in better profit. Her profits from the business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Nelia dreams that her business will continue to grow and hopes that their family will live in abundance. She meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and also to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for merchandise like ladies' shoes, shirts, toothpaste, lotion, deodorant, perfume, and other personal products needed in her business.

loans.name: Marieta

texts.en:
Marieta lives in Vanadzor, Armenia, and is a mother of two children, a daughter and a son. She is a 50-year-old widow and it is clear how difficult it is to take care of her family alone. Recently her daughter got married and now she lives separately from the rest of the family. Marieta’s son is still a school-aged boy.

Marieta has been engaged in retail sales for eight years; her small store is very popular in her district. She brings the products she needs for her store from Yerevan wholesale markets in a rented car. In her store, one can find different kinds of products: household items, beautiful vases for flowers, crockery, shampoo and hair brushes, etc. The variety of it is very large, so you can buy anything you need. Marieta has already taken a loan from Kiva once, and the success and support that she has had from it encouraged her to ask for help again. She needs 800,000 Armenian drams (AMD) to increase her store’s household goods from Yerevan wholesale markets. In this way, she has decided to increase the income from her trading.

loans.use: To increase her store’s stock of household items by buying merchandise from Yerevan wholesale markets.

loans.name: Sonia

texts.es: Sonia, de 35 años de edad , vive en su casa propia junto a su esposo y sus dos hijos quienes son su motor para salir adelante .Sonia se dedica a la venta de productos comestibles tales como arroz, azúcar, harina, aceite, huevos, entre otros , está actividad económica lo realiza en un pequeño local que esta ubicado en el interior de su vivienda. Lleva 07 años en éste negocio el cual se inicio por la necesidad de un empleo fijo y para ayudar con los gastos diarios a su esposo.Comenta que su negocio es rentable porque vende productos de primera necesidad y todos los días cuenta con buenos clientes .Espera poder seguir creciendo para construir un local  más amplio con todo lo necesario para la buena recepción y atención de sus clientes.Este es su sexto préstamo con Kiva y se siente agradecida por el apoyo financiero brindado.Con el monto solicitado de 1500 soles comprará productos comestibles tales como arroz, azúcar, harina, aceite, huevos, entre otros.
texts.en:
Sonia, thirty-five years old, lives in her own home along with her husband and two children, who are her drive to get ahead. Sonia sells consumable goods like rice, sugar, flour, oil, and eggs, among others. She runs this business out of a small space within her home.  She has seven years of experience with this business, which she started out of the need to find stable employment and to help her husband with the daily expenses. She says that her business is profitable because she sells necessities and she can rely on good customers every day. 

She hopes to continue growing so that she can build a larger space with everything she needs to provide good attention and reception to her customers. This is her sixth loan with Kiva and she is grateful for the financial support given. With this loan request of 1500 soles, she will buy consumable goods such as rice, sugar, flour, oil, and eggs, among other items.

loans.use: purchase consumable goods like rice, sugar, flour, and oil, among others.

loans.name: Deniza

texts.es: Deniza, de 65 años de edad , esta casada con Regner , juntos viven con su nieto en su propia casa .El trabajo de Deniza consiste  en la siembra de productos agrícolas tales como limón, mandarina y naranja aunque actualmente está preparando 02 piscigranjas  para la cría de  peces de la selva tales como, Paiche, Gamitada, Paco entre otros.  El lugar donde realiza está actividad  de siembra y cosecha se encuentra al frente de  su vivienda, cuenta con 8 hectáreas de terreno para está labor. Lleva 22 años en la siembra y cosecha  de productos cítricos. Comenta que  realiza el arado de la tierra, el abonado, la siembra, el riego y la cosecha junto a su esposo, su nieto y 02 obreros más quienes son de mucho apoyo en este tipo de labores. Luego junto a su esposo transportan el producto al mercado para asi ponerlos a la venta ya que sus productos son muy solicitados por los clientes.Espera seguir adelante en este negocio y continuar con el éxito que ahora tiene , por tanto éste será su préstamo número  07 con Kiva y se siente muy agradecida por el apoyo financiero brindado.Con le monto solicitado de 4000 soles comprará abono orgánico para sus sembríos.
texts.en: Deniza is 65 years old. She is married to Regner. They live together with their grandson in the home they own. Deniza's job is growing farm products such as lemons, tangerines and oranges, although right now she is preparing 2 fish farm pools to raise jungle fish such as paiche, gamitada, paco and more. The place where she does the planting and harvesting is in front of her house. she has 8 hectares for this work . She has been doing this for 22 years, planting and harvesting citrus. She says that she tills the earth, does the fertilizing, the planting, the irrigation and the harvesting with her husband, her grandson and 2 more workers who are a lot of help with this type of labors. Later, with her husband, she transports the product to the market to sell, because they are much sought after by customers. She hopes to keep going ahead with this business and continuing to have the success she has now. This will be loan number 7 with Kiva and she feels very grateful for the financial support that has been given. With the amount of 4000 soles that she has asked for, she will buy organic fertilizer for her crops.

loans.use: to buy organic fertilizer.

loans.name: Jose Eliseo

texts.es:
José, solicita un nuevo préstamo por la necesidad de más capital de trabajo  para invertir en el negocio; este le permitirá comprar pollos, concentrado e insumos para el crecimiento tales como: crecemur, punemar, entre otros.
El crédito anterior le ha ayudado a aumentar las ventas y un crecimiento en las utilidades; las condiciones económicas y las circunstancias familiares han mejorado.
texts.en:
José is requesting a new loan since he needs more working capital to invest in the business.  This will allow him to purchase chickens, feed, and supplies to raise them such as crecemur, punemar, and others.  

His last loan helped him increase his sales and grew his income.  His financial situation and family circumstances have improved.

loans.use: to purchase chickens, feed, and supplies to raise them.

loans.name: Segundo Raul

texts.es:
Segundo tiene 41 años de edad es casado tiene 5 hijos, vive con los hijos y la conyugue en la ciudad de Guaranda provincia de Bolívar.

Es integrante de la Ventanilla  Los pinos, se encuentra formada por 14 socios que son de la misma comunidad, se dedican a la agricultura queda a 40 minutos de la oficina Comunidad Pangua.

Segundo se dedica a la agricultura a la siembra de papas,  crianza de ganado y venta de quesos. Solicita el crédito para comprar un ganado vacuno. Con la ayuda del crédito podrá aumentar el ganado y mejorar la raza.  La compra lo realizará en la ciudad de Guaranda. 

El sueño tener terrenos para poder sembrar. Los desafíos a los que se enfrenta es la pobreza y la falta de recursos para realizar las compras. En el tiempo libre le gusta jugar boli y  disfrutar del carnaval.
texts.en:
Segundo is 41 years old. He is married and has 5 children. He lives with his children and his spouse in the city of Guaranda, province of Bolívar.

He is a member of the Los Pinos communal bank. It is made up of 14 members who are from the same community. They work in farming and are 40 minutes from the Pangua community office.

Segundo works in farming. He grows potatoes, raises cattle and sells cheese. He is asking for the loan to buy cattle. With the help of the loan, he will be able to increase the number of cattle he has and improve the breed. He will do his purchasing in the city of Guaranda. 

His dream is to have land to plant. the challenges he faces are poverty and the lack of resources to do his purchasing. In his free time, he likes to play volleyball and enjoy carnaval.

loans.use: to buy cattle.

loans.name: Anne Keru

texts.en:
My name is Anne. I am the first born in a family of three. I am in year two, currently pursuing a 4-year undergraduate degree in Actuarial Science and doing accounting at the same time. It has been a dream come true to be in Strathmore University because of its quality education and good brand name. This has been possible through a 40% Strathmore University scholarship. My grades have been good: scoring an average of an A in my first year.

I need a loan in order to purchase a laptop. I will ensure that I repay every month, so that other people can get access to Kiva loans in the future. The laptop loan will enable me to carry out extensive research, to do my assignments, and access notes in Strathmore's E-learning system. The laptop loan will also enable me to learn new skills online, like programming and Microsoft Excel, which I will learn by myself. This will enable me to be a better student and, therefore, realize my dream of being an actuary.

I am a hardworking, self-motivated and ambitious person with the desire for knowledge. I also love charity work, and I have participated in charitable activities like mentoring girls in Kitui, Kenya, and working in a children’s home. I intend to participate in the spirit of Kiva after I finish my studies, in order to make people’s dreams come true like mine.

loans.use: to buy a laptop to access E-learning and acquire IT skills

loans.name: Emeliana

texts.en:
Emeliana is 40 years old and has three children ages 10, 15 and 17. She is a sari-sari (general) store owner from Ubay, Bohol in the Philippines. She sells basic household goods like shampoo, toothpaste, sugar, cooking oil, seasoning and detergent. She is asking for a loan of 8,000 PHP to buy soft drinks, rice, canned goods and gasoline. This way, she will not run out of items that sell the most, maximizing her income.

In the future, she hopes to sell items that she does not offer at present to make a good profit for her children.

loans.use: to buy soft drinks, rice, canned goods and gasoline

loans.name: Aisha's Group

texts.en:
Aisha's group is composed of hardworking women. Aisha is 20 years old and lives in the town of Lugazi in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is married and has one child. For the past three years, Aisha has been working hard to manage her small food business, which sells fresh food. 

To help expand her business, Aisha has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more fresh food to sell, and will help Aisha to generate greater profits and take good care of herself and her family. Aisha hopes that in the future she will be able to expand the business and buy more different fresh foods. 

Aisha is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more fresh food to sell

loans.name: Thuan

texts.en:
Thuan was born in 1968. She has two children who are workers. Her husband raises pigs and chickens. His income is about 3,000,000 Viet Nam dongs (VND) per month. Thuan raises pigs and chickens, and plants vegetables to earn a living. She makes 3,000,000 VND a month. Her family’s total earnings are about 10,000,000 VND per month.

Thuan has participated in SEDA's credit program since 2003. In the last cycle, she borrowed 9,810,000 VND and repaid the loan on time. In this loan cycle, she would like to borrow 11,118,000 VND to buy more pigs and to plant vegetables. She wants to buy more new furniture for her house.

loans.use: to buy more pigs and to plant vegetables.

loans.name: Thoi

texts.en:
Thoi was born in 1959. She has two children; both of them are married. She is a widow. Thoi does carpentry to earn a living. Her income is about 2,000,000 VND. She has done this job for a very long time. Her family’s total earnings are about 6,000,000 VND per month. 
She has participated in SEDA's credit program since 2003. In the last cycle, she borrowed 9,810,000 VND and repaid the loan on time. In this loan cycle, she would like to again borrow 9,810,000 VND to buy wood for her carpentry workshop.

loans.use: to buy wood for her carpentry workshop.

loans.name: Garden View Group

texts.en:
Leah, who is in her early 50s, is married with two children. One of them is still at school and the other one is working. She has been running two businesses, a retail food shop and an electronics shop. She works from 7:00 a.m. to 9:00 p.m. daily and is able to make a very good monthly profit.

This will be Leah's twelfth loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loans to restock the out-of-stock items in the retail shop and the electronics shop. She has managed to pay back all her loans successfully. She will use this loan to restock the missing items in both shops, the food shop and the electronics shop. She used the profit from the previous loans to repair her house, pay school fees, and cover household expenses. Her dream is to one day be able to expand her business by traveling to Dubai.

Leah will share this loan with her loan group, Garden View, which has 10 members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to restock the missing items in her food shop and electronics shop.

loans.name: Erna

texts.en:
Erna is 45-year-old woman from the town of CPG, Bohol. She is married and has 7 children ages 9-23. Her husband works as a farmer and she has helped by weaving mats for 5 years now. Usually her mats are used for sleeping. She is asking for a loan to buy buri leaves and dye for coloring.  Any income generated from this venture goes towards food for the family and school fees of her children.

In the future, she hopes to make her business more profitable for her children.

loans.use: to buy buri leaves and dye

loans.name: Perlas De Oro Group

texts.es:
La A.C. “PERLAS DE ORO” iniciará el segundo ciclo en Pro Mujer, como parte del Centro Focal de German Busch, está compuesta por ocho  integrantes y está dirigida por una mesa directiva donde la señora Alicia es la Presidenta. Los negocios que las integrantes de la asociación comunal llevan adelante son variados entre ellos existen: venta de colchas, venta de frutas, pastelería, elaboración de taburetes, venta de pescado, venta de planchas, trenzado de mantas.

El crédito que sacaran beneficiara a pequeñas microempresarias donde la señora Alicia es integrante, ella indica que hace seis meses que integra Pro Mujer, ingresando por la invitación de su hermana que es socia de la institución. En la actualidad ella tiene un negocio de artesanía en tejido; da a conocer que este negocio lo emprendió por ser un negocio familiar hace varios años.
 
El crédito que ahora sacará es para el aumento de capital (compra de lana) que adquirirá de las ferias tradicionalistas de la ciudad de El Alto y posteriormente a la elaboración lo comercializará a pedido por mayor. Esta forma de trabajo le permite generar recursos para apoyar en lo posible a su hogar pues ella es casada y tiene cuatro hijos.  

Cuando se le consulta qué le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella responde que le gusta los créditos y el ahorro.
texts.en:
The communal bank "PERLAS DE ORO" (Pearls of Gold) will begin its second term in Pro Mujer (Pro Women), part of a Regional Office in the state of Germán Busch. It is composed of eight members and it is run by an executive board in which Alicia is the president. The members operate a variety of businesses, including the sales of quilts, bed sheets, fruit, and fish; a bakery; the decoration of footstools; and the crocheting of blankets.

The loan that they will take out will benefit the microbusinesses of which Alicia is one member. She said that they joined Pro Mujer six months ago at the invitation of her sister, who is a member of the institution.  Her current business is artisan crocheting. She said it began as a family business several years ago.

This loan will be used to increase her capital through the purchase of wool, which she will obtain from the traditional markets in the city of El Alto and later used in her craft, which she will sell wholesale by order. This type of work helps her earn income to support her home as much as possible, as she is married and has four children.

When asked what she liked about Pro Mujer, she replied that she liked the loans and the savings.

loans.use: purchase wool.

loans.name: Lilia

texts.en:
Lilia is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a variety store business in the Philippines. She successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further build her business. She is borrowing 18,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) through NWTF to purchase more items like sardines, snack foods and other groceries.

NWTF is presenting Lilia's business for funding of another loan in support of her efforts to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase more items like sardines, snack foods and other groceries.

loans.name: Jemal

texts.en:
Jemal is 27 years old. He lives in Khulo District with his wife and mother in-law. Jemal requested a loan from local financial institutions several times for a  family business start-up, without any success. His loan request was rejected each time, because of low income and the family’s poor living conditions. 
The family does not have a source of income. According to Credo estimations the family belongs to the subsistence poor category.

Jemal requested a loan from Credo to start-up a family business. Jemal has now been approved for a loan within the framework of the new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages provision of a business start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions to rural poor people, who do not have access to credit products. These rural poor people are regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of their low income. With his credit Jemal will purchase grocery inventory to open a grocery shop. He already has a commercial space ready to open a shop. After purchasing the inventory the family will start working in the shop themselves to decrease the expenses of paying salary to somebody else. This will increase the profit. Part of the profit they make will be used for reinvesting in the same business, in order to have a better variety of merchandise to offer to the clients and another part will be used for the family's well being.

loans.use: to purchase inventory to open a grocery store

loans.name: Yamileth De Los Angeles

texts.es: Doña Yamileth habita en el municipio de Ticuantepe junto a su esposo e hijas, ella tiene su propio negocio es modista desde hace 15 años, su esposo trabaja como mecánico, ambos de esa manera se apoyan para brindarle a sus  hijas lo necesario como los estudios, ropa, comida y con los gastos del hogar, con el credito anterior construyeron un cuarto para tener mejor espacio y comodidad en el hogar, con este nuevo financiamiento comprara Materiales como: Arena, Cemento, Pintura, Puertas para darle el acabado a su cuarto, Agradece el apoyo que Afodenic atravez de Fondos Kiva le han brindado.
texts.en:
Yamileth lives in the Ticuantepe municipality with her husband and daughters.  She has had her own dressmaking business for 15 years.  Her husband works as a mechanic.  In this way, they support each other so they can provide their children with what they need for their education, clothing, and food and with the household expenses.

With the previous loan they built a room in order to have more space and comfort in their home.  With this new loan she will buy construction materials like sand, cement, paint, and doors in order to give the room the finishing touches.

She is grateful for the support from Afodenic through the Kiva loans she has been granted.

loans.use: to buy construction materials.

loans.name: Lilian

texts.en:
Lilian is a married woman and has four children, all of which attend school. She rents a house that has electricity, but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

She operates a food making business, making beans and chapati (flat bread) for sale to passersby and neighbors. With the 20,000 KES loan she wants to purchase food items such as wheat flour, cooking fat, sugar and beans. She dreams of expanding her business to earn more income and establish a restaurant in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase food items: wheat flour, cooking fat, sugar and beans.

loans.name: Jolan

texts.en:
Jolan is a married man and has one child. Jolan is 28 years old and resides in Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur: Philippines. Jolan is operating a fishing business venture, selling seafood products including crabs and shrimp in the local community to earn a living.  He has been in this business 2 years and earns 3,000 PHP monthly.

He requested a loan of 5,000.00 to purchase fishing equipment including hooks & nets. This year, Jolan joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his business and living conditions.  In the future, he hopes to improve his fishing equipment.

loans.use: to purchase fishing equipment including hooks & nets

loans.name: Jenalyn

texts.en:
Jenalyn is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a general store business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing 30,000 PHP through NWTF to purchase more groceries to sell to her customers.

NWTF is re-listing Jenalyn's business profile again in support of her efforts to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Abita

texts.en: Abita is a fish vendor from the town of Lila, Bohol. She is a married woman and a mother of two grown up children. Abita is asking for a loan to buy more fish to sell. With this, she will be able to improve her sales and profits. Abita wants to make her fish vending a stable source of income.

loans.use: to buy more fish to sell

loans.name: Phuong

texts.en:
Phuong was born in 1974. She has one child who is in the fifth grade. She is a single mother. To earn a living, Phuong raises chickens. Her income is about 4,000,000 VND. 

She has participated in SEDA's credit program since 2006. In the last cycle she borrowed 9,810,000 VND and repaid the loan on time. In this loan cycle, she would like to borrow 9,810,000 VND to raise more chickens. She wants to raise her children up well.

loans.use: to buy more chickens to raise

loans.name: Joan

texts.en:
Joan is 16 years old and lives in the town of Lugazi in the Mukono region of Uganda. For the past 2 years, Joan has been working hard to manage her poultry farm, which sells chicken. 

To help expand her business, Joan has requested a loan of 250,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more poultry chicks to sell, and will help Joan to generate greater profits and improve her family's standards of living. Joan hopes that in the future she will be able to expand on the poultry farm and add more chicks. 

Joan is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more poultry chicks to sell

loans.name: Guadalupe

texts.en:
Guadalupe works hard to support her family. She is married and has a fishing business in the Philippines.

Guadalupe requested a 12,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy fishing nets and other equipment.  She has been in this business for 2 years.

In the future, Guadalupe would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy fishing nets and other equipment

loans.name: Phien

texts.en:
Phien was born in 1963. She has two children who are all married. Her husband is a worker and earns about 3,000,000 (VND) per month. Phien is a farmer. She makes 3,000,000 dong (VND) a month from it. Her family’s total earnings are about 6,000,000 VND per month. 

Phien has participated in SEDA's credit program since 2006. In the last cycle, she borrowed 6,758,000 VND and repaid the loan on time. In this loan cycle, she would like to borrow 8,066,000 VND to buy more pigs and grow rice. She wants to buy more new furniture for her house.

loans.use: to buy more pigs and grow rice

loans.name: Umazi

texts.en:
Umazi is a very hardworking and enterprising woman who says that she has been able to greatly increase her income and help her family, thanks to her hard work.

She is asking for a loan of KES 25,000 to buy ingredients such as wheat flour, maize flour, rice and sugar that will help her to invest back into her business. She is grateful for the new support she is receiving.

loans.use: to buy ingredients such as wheat flour, maize flour, rice and sugar

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en: Josephine into selling of food stuffs but took her loan to sells cosmetics in Likpe Bakua, Hohoe Township and the surrounding communities. Josephine has received no formal education.  She is widow with 5 children. Josephine has been selling food stuffs and other petty trading for the past 18 years but took loan to sells powder so she can get an extra income to support herself. She is responsible for all the financial needs of herself and that of her children. She started selling cosmetics so she can give great support to her children. Her loan will be used to buy more cosmetics to sell. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save towards her children's schooling needs.

loans.use: to buy more cosmetics.

loans.name: Awulata

texts.en:
Awulata is married with 2 children. She has received schooling till the end of Junior High School. Currently, Awulata sells veils and clothes in Wisdom Mpeasem (near Cape Coast). She has been involved in this business for about five years now. Her husband is a businessman. 

Awulata's income goes towards helping her husband pay for the family's general expenses. Awulata will use the loan to increase her existing inventory of veils and clothes. With the new profits from her expanded enterprise, Awulata plans to develop her business further by venturing into newer markets.

loans.use: to increase her existing inventory of veils and clothes.

loans.name: Efua

texts.en: Efua is single and has four children. Even though she did not receive any formal education, Efua is a successful businesswoman. She is a seamstress in Wisdom Mpeasem (near Cape Coast). She has been actively involved in this business for about 15 years. As the sole breadwinner in the family, Efua uses her income to provide for the entire family. Efua will use the loan to purchase tools and equipment, thus helping her to improve her overall sewing and sales. With the new profits from her expanded business, Efua will diversify her inventory to adapt to customer's changing preferences.

loans.use: to purchase tools and equipment, thus helping her to improve her overall sewing and sales.

loans.name: Akwesi

texts.en: After graduating from Junior High School, Akwesi decided to set up his own bicycle repair business in Domenase (near Cape Coast). With over 15 years of experience, he is currently looking to expand his enterprise further. Unfortunately, he is limited due to a lack of funding. As a result, this loan will be used to help him purchase more tools and parts to expand his business. He aims at using the profits from his business to help support his wife (who is a trader) with the upkeep of their house, whilst ensuring that their four children are able to experience a better life.

loans.use: to help him purchase more tools and parts to expand his business.

loans.name: Aba

texts.en: Aba is married and has six children.  She has received some schooling through the completion of middle school.  Currently, Aba sells cooked rice in Domenase, which is near Cape Coast.  She has been involved in this business for about seven years now.  Her husband is a mason and Aba’s income helps him meet the family's general expenses.  Aba will use the loan to buy more rice to cook and sell.  With the new profits from her expanded enterprise, Aba plans to develop her business further by venturing into new markets.

loans.use: to buy more rice to cook and sell

loans.name: Marcelo

texts.en:
Marcelo is 25 years old and married with a two-month-old baby girl to support. He is from Ubay, Bohol. Marcelo is in the fishing business to support the needs of his family. His fishing business started five years ago. 

He is asking for a loan of 5,000 PHP to buy fishing hooks, fishing net and gasoline. Marcelo knows that he can do more with the needed capital for fishing. 

In the future, he hopes to improve his fishing business for a better income.

loans.use: to buy fishing hooks, fishing net and gasoline

loans.name: Ellen

texts.en:
Ellen is a 32-year-old married woman with three children. She owns and operates a fishing business, and sells fish in the local community. She's been in this business for four years, earning 3,000 PHP a month for a living. 

Ellen joined GDMPC in 2011 to gain access to micro finance. She is now requesting 4,000 PHP to purchase new fishing net. In the future, she plans to buy another fishing boat.

loans.use: to purchase new fishing net

loans.name: Lan

texts.en:
Lan was born in 1988. She has two children who are still little. She and her husband sell votive papers. Her family’s total earnings are about 6,000,000 VND per month. 

Lan has participated in the Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance (SEDA) credit program since 2013. In this first loan cycle, she would like to borrow 5,014,000 VND to buy more tools to make votive papers. She wants to buy more new furniture for her house.

loans.use: to buy more tools to make votive papers

loans.name: Anna

texts.en: Anna lives in Ddmashen village in the region of Gegharkunik. She is 48 years old. She lives with her husband, son and with her retired mother-in-law. Her husband is unemployed and he helps Anna in farming. Anna’s son works as a police inspector and a makes a small salary. Anna has never worked and since getting married she has been engaged in farming. In their farm they have 4 cows, 2 calves and 30 chickens. Anna’s son sometimes helps her in farming. Anna is a very hard working woman, but the work in the farm is a lot and problems are a lot as well. So she decided to ask for a loan from Kiva in order to be able to buy fuel for the land cultivation process, fodder for her animals, and potato seedlings. She hopes that Kiva lenders will give her a chance to significantly improve their living conditions

loans.use: to buy fuel for land cultivation process, fodder for her animals, and potato seedlings

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en:
Gladys lives in the Eldoret area of Kenya, which is training grounds for many of Kenya's Olympic runners. She has two children and has been doing this work for three years.  Her primary income sources are milk, eggs, crops, and the salary from her job.

She stated what is most enjoyable about farming: 'Farming is enjoyable apart from being a major source of income' Her biggest challenge is 'Weather flactuation, price descrimination, high input prices..' Animals on the farm have been given the names of 'Chemobet.'

Gladys was asked why she chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan, to which she replied: 'Was introduced to Juhudi Kilimo by a group member.'  This client was also asked what was learned during Juhudi's required micro-finance training session: 'How one could benefit from an Micro Finance Institution to boost capital and repay the loan with ease.'

Gladys's highest monthly expense is farming costs. When asked 'How will this loan benefit her family', Gladys replied, 'Will be able to increase acreage for more production.'

As part of Juhudi's loan appraisal process, each borrower's assets are evaluated. Gladys owns the following: 'cow, poultry' but does not own 'pig, pump, bicycle, motorcycle, automobile'. Juhudi Kilimo also tries to measure any change in living standards based on this loan.

Note: To create this loan profile, Juhudi Kilimo used a mobile device to gather information in the field and send the data to a central online repository, thus reducing paper use, making the process more efficient, and keeping costs down."

loans.use: To improve her horticultural farming

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David is 49 years old. He lives in the village of Tetritsklebi, Telavi District with his wife and two children (12 and 17 years old). David requested loans from local financial institutions several times for family business start-up, but without any success. His loan requests were rejected all the time, because of low income and family’s poor living conditions. 

The family runs an agricultural business. In particular, they have four milk cows and a plot of agricultural land, where apple trees are grown. The cows are milked every day to make cheese. Harvested apples and cheese are sold locally at the markets and the family gets a small monthly income. This is the only source of living for them, which is rarely enough for covering the food expenses.  

David requested loan from Credo to start up a family business. David has now been approved for a loan within the framework of the new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages provision of business start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions to rural poor people, who do not have access to credit products. These rural poor people are regarded as “high-risk borrowers” because of their low income. 

With his credit, David will purchase chicks. He will raise the chicks and sell them later at a higher price to earn a good profit. Part of the profit David will use to reinvest in the same business and develop his farming. Another part will be used to cover family monthly expenses and provide for his children's future studies.

loans.use: To purchase chicks

loans.name: Evangeline

texts.en: Evangeline is applying for a new loan of PHP 30,000 to buy ingredients for her food business. Her business was previously funded through Kiva partner NWTF, and continues to provide Evangeline and her family with income that is improving their quality of life.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her food business.

loans.name: Anaclita

texts.en: Anaclita is involved in a kalamay making business in her place in Albur, Bohol. Kalamay is a sticky sweet delicacy that is popular in many regions of the Philippines. It is made of coconut milk, brown sugar, and ground glutinous rice (Wikipedia). This is the source of her income. Anaclita is asking for a loan to buy glutinuous rice, sugar, peanuts and others. Through this, she will be able to make more kalamay and sell more thus increasing her sales and income.  In the future, Anaclita hopes of making her business a success.

loans.use: to buy glutinuous rice, sugar, peanuts and other necessary items

loans.name: Regina

texts.en:
Regina is married and she works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 10000 loan through NWTF to purchase more stocks to sell.

Regina has been in this business for nine years and has previously received funds through Kiva.

Regina aspires to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase more inventory to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase additional stock, in preparation for the coming winter season

loans.name: Nathan

texts.en:
Nathan is a 34-year-old man from Kakamega, which is located in the western part of Kenya. He is married and supports five people in his family, including his four children, ages 15, 13, 10 and 5 years old.

Nathan supplies bread to the retail shop owners in his local market. He has been doing this for the last 14 years and comfortably makes a monthly income of 40,000 KES. Nathan applied for his third loan with KADET LTD, which he will use to purchase more bread for his supply. This will increase his volume of sales and bring in more income. He will put the anticipated profit back into the business.

His dream is to start a bakery and to improve his family’s living standards.

loans.use: To purchase more bread for resale in the market.

loans.name: Marlita

texts.en:
Marlita is a 46-years-old married woman from Ubay, Bohol. She has six children ages 10-26. Marlita is involved in a fresh fish and crabs retail business for 10 years now. Her family is also involved in the fishing business. She usually earns 4,000 PHP per month from these businesses. She is asking for a loan of 10,000 PHP to buy more fresh fish, crabs and fishing nets. The additional capital will help boost Marlita's business and income.

In the future, she hopes to have another business to generate more profits.

loans.use: to buy more fresh fish, crabs and fishing nets

loans.name: Kadzo

texts.en: Kadzo is taking out another Kiva loan, in the amount of KES 50,000. She will use the loan to expand her existing business. With the loan, she wants to purchase household consumables to resell at her kiosk, including wheat flour, maize flour, and rice. She is grateful to Kiva lenders and Yehu Microfinance, for the opportunity.

loans.use: to purchase household consumables to resell, including wheat flour, maize flour, and rice.

loans.name: Belinda

texts.en: Belinda, age 37, is married with three children. She lives in Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur in the Phillipines. Belinda manages a general store for a living. The work gives her a total monthly income of 4,500 PHP. In 2008, she joined GDMPC and is now requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP to purchase additional products like canned goods, noodles, sugar and coffee to sell in her store. She hopes to save a portion of her earnings for maintenance costs and to expand her current store.

loans.use: to purchase additional products like canned goods, noodles, sugar and coffee to sell in her store.

loans.name: Amalia

texts.en:
As a married mother of four children, Amalia works hard to support her family. She has a charcoal retailing business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from a general store.  Amalia is borrowing 30,000 PHP to purchase more charcoal stock to sell.

Amalia has been sustaining her business activities through her past 17 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her reach her dream: saving enough money to send her children to school.

loans.use: to purchase more charcoal stock to sell.

loans.name: Mahross

texts.en: Mahross is a 38-year-old married man who lives in Sana`a, Yemen with three children.  He runs a grocery store for 4 years and earns a low daily income.  He worked really hard and lives in a poor area.  He said that he couldn`t provide for his family`s needs permanently due to his business not running well.  He would like to expand his business.  He applied for a loan of 199,999 YER from AMB to buy new products for his grocery store in order to expand his business.  In the future, he hopes to improve his living standards so he could apply his increased profits to his family’s needs.

loans.use: to buy new products for his grocery store to expand his business.

loans.name: Solomon

texts.en:
Solomon is a man of thirty-five years, married to Grace and a father of three children. He runs a general store in Muchatha, in the outskirts of Kangemi. He has been in this business for six years. Solomon earns a monthly income of 54,000 shillings (KES).

This will be Solomon's third loan from KADET LTD. He plans to use the entire loan to add to his inventory by purchasing home products made of plastic, like basins, jugs and cups. He wants to own a supermarket, in the future.

loans.use: To purchase plastic goods to resell, like basins, jugs and cups

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay to have her land cleared for farming.

loans.name: Concepcion

texts.en:
Concepcion is 61 years old and married with 13 children.  She works hard to provide for her family by running a general store in the Philippines.  Concepcion requested a 10,000 PHP loan through NWTF to purchase rice, canned goods, sugar, and other groceries.

Concepcion has borrowed and paid nine loans from NWTF before this loan.  She has been running the general store for 10 years and also earns an income from a cafeteria.  Concepcion aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase groceries including rice, canned goods, and sugar.

loans.name: Catalina

texts.en: Catalina is a 36-year-old married woman with five children from Panglao, Bohol.  She runs a food vending business selling snack foods such as tempura and other items.  This is the source of her income.  Catalina is asking for a loan to buy ingredients for her business like flour, cooking oil, and seasonings.  Through this, she will be able to sell more thus augmenting her sales and income.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her food  vending business such as flour, cooking oil, and seasonings.

loans.name: Merab

texts.en: Merab is an ambitious woman living in Masindi-Uganda. She sells clothes and she started the business in order to supplement her farming activities. Her personal goals are to educate her children and build a permanent house for residence. Ever changing customer preferences and price fluctuation are her major challenges while her dreams are to own a modern boutique. Merab intends to use the loan to buy clothes to sell.

loans.use: to buy clothes to sell

loans.name: Luvuno

texts.en: Luvuno is a hardworking lady who strives hard to improve her life.  She appreciates the previous help and is here again for another loan of 50,000 KES to buy more brooms to sell to satisfy her clients and avoid shortages of the stock.

loans.use: to buy more brooms for sale to satisfy her clients

loans.name: Tho

texts.en:
Tho was born in 1967. She has three children. Her youngest child is in primary school. The middle one is in high school and the eldest is a worker. Her husband is a carpenter. His income is about 5,000,000 VND per month. Tho is a farmer and a carpenter. She earns 5,000,000 VND a month. Her family’s total earnings are about 8,000,000 VND per month.

She has participated in SEDA's credit program since 2012. In the last cycle she borrowed 5,014,000 VND and repaid the loan on time. In this loan cycle, she would like to borrow 6,322,000 VND to buy more wood for her carpentry shop. She wants to raise her children well, so they can get a job in the future.

loans.use: to buy more wood for her carpentry shop

loans.name: Tinh

texts.en:
Tinh was born in 1981. She has two children who are little. Her husband is a worker. His income is about 4,000,000 VND. 

Tinh has a grocery store and earns about 3,000,000 VND per month. The total earnings of her family is about 7,000,000 VND per month. 

She has participated in SEDA's credit program since 2003. In the last cycle she borrowed 9,810,000 VND and repaid the loan on time. In this loan cycle, she would like to borrow 10,246,000 VND to buy more candies, cakes and noodles for her grocery store. She hopes her business makes enough money to pay for her children’s education fees.

loans.use: to buy more candies, cakes and noodles for her grocery store

loans.name: Danilo

texts.en:
Danilo has been engaged in copra buying and charcoal sales, for more than three years. This is the source of his income. He is a married man and has four children.

Danilo is asking for a loan to buy more copra. (Copra is the dried, white flesh of the coconut, from which coconut oil is extracted.) Through this, he will be able to augment his income and improve his business. Danilo hopes to repay his loan on time, to expand his business in the future, and to save money for the schooling of his children.

loans.use: to buy more copra

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a variety of cellular phones and spare parts and accessories for them.

loans.name: Norma

texts.en: Norma is a 49-year-old married woman and the mother of six children from Dauis, Bohol. She has been operating a sari-sari store for more than five years now. She sells various goods and items to the people in her place. Norma is asking for a loan to buy more merchandise to sell like soda and beverages, soap and toiletries, noodles, canned goods, and others. Through this, she will be able to attract and serve more customers in her store, thus, augmenting her sales and income. In the future, Norma dreams of making her business a success.

loans.use: to buy more merchandise to sell like soda and beverages, soap and toiletries, noodles, canned goods, and others

loans.name: Merceditha

texts.en:
Merceditha is a 44-year-old rice farmer from the municipality of Ubay, Bohol.  She is married with six children, ages 2 to 25. Her loan will be used to buy fertilizer for her field.  This loan will help to sustain her business and keep her farm productive. 

Merceditha is looking forward to a higher yield from her crops with the help of this loan. Any income will be used for family consumption and to pay her children’s school fees. In the future, she hopes to send her children to school and make a good life from her business.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer for use in her field.

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en:
Ahmad is a 27-year-old single man who has been working as a barber for twelve years.  He was only 15 years old when he started working to help with his family's living.  In 2009, he opened his own shop and made a special part of it for kids, decorated with pictures, characters, and floor coverings.

Ahmad is applying for a youth loan from Kiva's partner, Al Majmoua, in order to buy new tools and furniture for his business.  Through this loan he will be able to develop his business to attract new customers.

Ahmad is a hard worker.  He plans to keep developing his business as much as he can to please his customers.  He especially wants to please the children by providing them with new haircuts and gifts to make sure they stay loyal to him and bring in their parents for a cool haircut.  He hopes to continue developing his business and to make a small family of his own in the future.

loans.use: to buy new tools and furniture for his business.

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a fishing business in the Philippines.  She is borrowing 27,000 PHP through NWTF to buy fishing nets, bamboo, and other fishing equipment.  Erlinda has been in this business for 21 years.  She earns additional income from a general store.

Erlinda has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF.  She dreams to save enough money to expand her business and to repair her family home.

loans.use: to buy fishing nets, bamboo, and other fishing equipment.

loans.name: Jona

texts.en:
As a married parent of five children, Jona works hard to support her family. She has a fishing business in the Philippines, and she earns additional income from keeping a general store.

Jona is borrowing PHP 22,000 through NWTF. She will use the loan to buy fishing gear, for her fishing business. She has been sustaining her business activities through her past 18 loans from NWTF and, more recently, from Kiva lenders. She hopes that her hard work will help her to attain her dream -- to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy fishing gear

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy produce such as maize and beans to sell

loans.name: Maura

texts.en:
Maura is 49 years old and married with three children. She earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines. Maura is borrowing 15,000 PHP to purchase feed and vitamins for her pigs.

Maura has been raising pigs for eleven years and also earns additional income from a general store. She is working tirelessly to attain her dream of saving enough money to expand her business and send her children to school.

loans.use: to purchase feed and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Leonida

texts.en:
Leonida is 48-years-old, married and has nine children, five of her children are in school. She is a very hard working entrepreneur.

Leonida has a fishing business in the Philippines. Leonida requested a 25,000 PHP loan amount through NWTF to buy fishing nets and other equipment.

Leonida has been in this business for twenty years. In the future, Leonida would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college and expand her business.

loans.use: to buy fishing nets and other equipment

loans.name: Isaya

texts.en: Isaya is 22-years-old, married, has one child and lives in Fort Portal, Uganda. He is a tea farmer but also hawks general merchandise to earn a daily income in order to meet his family's expenses. Unpredictable weather changes and inadequate capital affect his profits while his dreams are to buy more land and farm extensively. Isaya is requesting for a loan to plant more tea.

loans.use: to plant more tea

loans.name: Olga Abigail

texts.es:
Olga tiene 19 años de edad es soltera no tiene hijos, vive con unos familiares en la ciudad de Guaranda provincia de Bolívar.

Es integrante de la Ventanilla  Los pinos, se encuentra formada por 14 socios que son de la misma comunidad, se dedican a la agricultura queda a 40 minutos de la oficina Comunidad Pangua.

Olga se dedica al comercio a la venta de todo tipo de grano además se dedica a la crianza de ganado, cerdos.
 Solicita el crédito para comprar una cocina industrial de seis hornillas. Con la ayuda del crédito podrá comprar el artefacto.

Las compras las realizará en la ciudad de Guaranda y las ventas las realiza dentro y fuera de la provincia Bolívar.
El sueño es mejorar el negocio superarse en la vida y tener una vida segura. Los desafíos a los que se enfrenta es la economía y la competencia.

En el tiempo libre le gusta disfrutar día a día de lo maravilloso de la vida.
texts.en:
Olga, who is 19 years old, is single and has no children. She lives with relatives in the city of Guaranda, in the province of Bolivar.

She is a member of the communal bank "Los Pinos," which was formed by 14 members who are from the same community. They work in agriculture and are located 40 minutes from the Pangua community  office.

Olga sells all types of grains. In addition, she raises cattle and pigs. She is applying for the loan to buy an industrial stove with six burners. With the help of the loan, she will be able to buy this appliance.

She makes her purchases in the city of Guaranda and completes her sales within and outside of the province of Bolivar. Her dream is to improve her business, get ahead in life, and have a secure life. The challenges that she faces are the economy and competition.

In her free time she likes to enjoy the day-to-day wonders of life.

loans.use: to buy an industrial stove with six burners.

loans.name: Liezyl

texts.en:
